thread.title: Madonna Thought About ‘Blowing Up the White House,’ Unloads F-Bombs in Speech (Video)
thread.title_full: Madonna Thought About ‘Blowing Up the White House,’ Unloads F-Bombs in Speech (Video)

author: Jeremy Fuster
title: Madonna Thought About ‘Blowing Up the White House,’ Unloads F-Bombs in Speech (Video)
text:
Search Madonna Thought About ‘Blowing Up the White House,’ Unloads F-Bombs in Speech (Video) 
Madge urged the Women’s March in Washington D.C. crowd to reject “this new age of tyranny” Jeremy Fuster | January 21, 2017 @ 3:20 PM 
Madonna was one among dozens of celebs who welcomed the 500,000 protesters in attendance to the “revolution of love” at Saturday’s Women’s March on Washington. But Madge made it clear that a revolution of love has room for a few f-bombs. 
At three different points during her speech, Madonna let loose some profanity to the cheers of those in attendance. After the third f-bomb was dropped, CNN and MSNBC cut away from her speech, with CNN’s Brooke Baldwin apologizing for airing the profanity uncensored. C-SPAN, meanwhile, aired her speech in its entirety. Also Read: Ashley Judd to Trump Supporters in Her Family: ‘You Voted for a “P—y Grabber’ (Video) 
Madonna opened her speech by urging Americans to reject “this new age of tyranny, where not just women are in danger but all marginalized people, where being uniquely different right now might truly be considered a crime. It took this horrific moment of darkness to wake us the f— up.” 
She later said, “To our detractors that insist that this march will never add up to anything, f— you.” 
But conservative commentators took exception most to Madonna ‘s remark that she had “thought an awful lot about blowing up the White House, but I know this won’t change anything.” Instead, Madonna said that rather than falling into despair, she would “choose love.” Madonna ‘s guaranteed all the headlines will now be about her White House bomb threat & F-word rant. She’s wrecked the #WomensMarch . 
- Piers Morgan (@piersmorgan) January 21, 2017 
Madonna ?src=hash”># Madonna is a pathetic, washed-up, has-been who apparently thinks that threatening @realDonaldTrump will somehow spark her dead career. 
- David Wohl (@DavidWohl) January 21, 2017 I hope conservatives aren’t pretending to be outraged over Madonna ‘s “f*ck you”. They told us words don’t matter, then elected a vulgarian. 
- Sarah Reese Jones (@PoliticusSarah) January 21, 2017 
“It seems as though we had all slipped into a false sense of comfort, that justice would prevail, that good would win in the end,” Madonna said. “Well, good did not win this election, but good will win in the end. So what today means is that we are far from the end. Today marks the beginning, the beginning of our story. The revolution starts here, the fight for the right to be free, to be who we are, to be equal.” 
“Let’s march together through this darkness and with each step know that we are not afraid, that we are not alone, that we will not back down, that there is power in our unity and that no opposing force stands a chance in the face of true solidarity.” 
You can watch Madonna speech in its entirety in the clip above. Best Signs From the Women's March (Updating Photos) 
Millions of people worldwide have taken over the streets in protest of Donald Trump's presidency. Protesters brought out their best signs and slogans as they condemned Trump's comments about women, minorities, Muslims, the LGBT community and the GOP's plans to crack down on undocumented Americans and Planned Parenthood. TheWrap/Matt Pressberg 
A protester holds up a sign inspired by Angry Cat. TheWrap/Matt Pressberg 
Tens of thousands gathered in Pershing Square in L.A. as early as 8 A.M. TheWrap/Tim Molloy 
Metro trains into downtown Los Angeles were reportedly at overcapacity. TheWrap/Tim Molloy 
Many signs attacked Trump for his "grab by the p---y" comments leaked from NBC's "Access Hollywood" archives. TheWrap/Matt Pressberg 
The march went from Pershing Square to Grand Park, located adjacent to L.A.'s City Hall. TheWrap/Matt Pressberg 
The First Lady was not left unforgotten. TheWrap/Tim Molloy 
Men stood by the women of the U.S. in solidarity. TheWrap/Tim Molloy 
A doctored emoji illustrated this petitioner's words. TheWrap/Tim Molloy 
And there are two words we never thought we'd see together. TheWrap/Tim Molloy 
Carrie Fisher, apparently, was there in spirit. TheWrap/Tim Molloy Next Slide 1 of 11 
More than a million people have taken to the streets to protest the new leaders in the White House 
Millions of people worldwide have taken over the streets in protest of Donald Trump's presidency. Protesters brought out their best signs and slogans as they condemned Trump's comments about women, minorities, Muslims, the LGBT community and the GOP's plans to crack down on undocumented Americans and Planned Parenthood.
